blog.description: Mr. Merenda is a high school science teacher bringing you Fun Facts from comics, movies, TV, video games, and more every weekday!  He also boasts an impressive collection of over 500 TIES, which along with his many collectibles, are on display for you right here!

blog.name: greatrunner
blog.title: Give my Regards to the Inferno!
blog.description:
greatrunner | 30 | Sagittarius | Writer. | Professional Heel. | Formerly everyleaffallstoosoon and vemeer-mark-iv | banner: ironmacn

Hello, strange wanderer of the tumblrsphere of danger. This is a blogsphere for my personal likes and interests. If you're interested in what I happen to be interested in, check out my archive, tags and navigation. This is not a spoiler free zone, I usually don't mark spoilers. This blog contains blood, gore and body horror. Basically it contains content that isn’t for thirteen and under audiences, so please don’t follow me if you aren’t 18+. Thanks for visiting, tho.

summary: Mary Jane, Old Arguments, and Authorial Intent
title: Mary Jane, Old Arguments, and Authorial Intent
body:
I have no real problems with Mary Jane being a reporter instead of a model or actress, especially considering that’s the path she was on (more or less) near the end of the Ultimate Marvel series in Ultimate Comics Spider-Man (IIRC). (I don’t think that was exclusive to the Disney cartoon.)

(If you can deal with her being a mother and a superhero, sometimes both at the same time, you can deal with her not being a model/actress in every iteration there is for her).

It certainly is more convenient for the game’s narrative. (it’s akin to the 2016 Frequency remake making Frank Sullivan a police officer versus a fireman who clumsily detective’ed his way through a serial killer case). I like the switch, especially since Peter (in this iteration of his story) is more scientist than he is reporter. (But, I also like Peter telling Mary Jane the truth in USM, so you know where I stand in general, I guess.) 

Insomniac’s writing for Mary Jane for the most part, is fairly solid, but there are times where it’s pretty… irresponsible (for lack of a better word). That, or just really inconsistent for the sake of “character does things because plot”.  I like reporter Mary Jane, what I’m not crazy about, I guess, is that making her a reporter for the Daily Bugle seems, not at all inspired by other canon material, but a tried and true argument that has become pretty disingenuous over the years.

For the most part, a lot of the writing early on in the game never presents Mary Jane or Peter Parker’s relationship as one where Peter is overprotective or dismissive of her journalistic efforts. Hell, he doesn’t even talk down to her when she decides to jump into situation wherein she could be hurt. He just expresses his worry.

Her introduction, for instance, wherein she is trying to expose Fisk for stealing (?) historical art pieces and selling them off as legit purchases, demonstrates nothing but complete trust between the two characters, especially with regard to what she can and cannot do. Mary Jane can sneak up on a guy and knock him out (when he’s distracted), as long as there aren’t other men around that can kill her the next second.

Mary Jane knows she can’t fight or even handle the Martin Li’s “Demon gang”, so she removes herself from the equation by hiding somewhere, and only ends up in the middle of things when one of Li’s henchmen is smart enough to do a thorough search of the exhibit she’s in. Then Peter has to come and help her out. 

Afterward, a lot of Peter and Mary Jane’s interaction highlights and centralizes her primary skill in this universe: investigation, digging things up, the thing that’s kinda integral to her job at the Daily Bugle. It even demonstrates, for the most part, that her devil-may-care antics come with legal consequences (not that they appear lasting or impactful, but they’re there). And, never once does she complain about having to look things up, either for herself or for Peter – especially when they start working on the same story (the “Demon gang”).

But, following Wilson Fisk’s arrest and the introduction of Martin Li (Mr. Negative) as the antagonist, Mary Jane’s attitude toward Peter becomes questionably antagonistic. A lot of it is an artificial conflict so that Peter and Mary Jane have something to fight about. (It’s not enough that their not together because of issues with him being Spider-Man 80% of the time, as usual.) 

Mary Jane starts taking what are, really, some seriously unnecessary risks to get answers for questions she might’ve uncovered by just talking to the persons in question or nosing into people’s paper trails. Like, instead of stealth segments, maybe we could’ve gotten L.A. Noir type levels with Mary Jane trying to investigate crimes for articles. Hell, that would’ve been a perfect excuse to use Yuri Watanabe more in the narrative outside of phone calls and brief cinematics, but I digress.

Instead, she goes straight into armed gunman territory to speak to one of Osborn’s aide’s (around the same time Peter is), without telling Peter about it. She nearly causes a scene by surprising said aide, and then again when Peter drops in when rescues her from what he assumed was a mercenary working for Silver Sable. She then proceeds to get mad at Peter for admonishing her actions, showing the slightest concern about her decisions, and behaves as though Peter told her to stay out of the situation (when that never occurred).

She even goes as far as to say that the reason they broke up (in this universe) is because he was somehow impeding her career as a journalist, when the reason, as usual, seems to be she just got frustrated with how much time he dedicated to being Spider-Man versus his interpersonal relationships (which is why the narrative has him repeatedly emphasize that his work with Doctor Octopus is the better time sink. He has time for a personal life, at the very least).

But, the narrative never treats her comments as though, out of frustration, she blindly assigned blame of their relationship problems on the wrong issue (in this particular instance). It’s a fact, despite Peter’s protests to otherwise (which I guess are just wrong?).

The narrative paints this image that instead of doing what they were doing in the introduction level, Peter has spent most of her career at the Bugle (and before that), telling her what she can and cannot investigate based on the level of danger, when the most he’s done is say, “Mary Jane this is dangerous. Did you really think this all the way through? Why didn’t tell me about this so I could help you?” 

There’s this insistence from Mary Jane that the two of them are partners or could be partners, but that partnership is based only on when its useful for her, and then when she gets into a situation that actually requires his help, she bristles when he points out she was acting recklessly then proceeds to give him the silent treatment.

And, obviously, the two finally sit down and talk. She apologies for acting the way she does (after the Grand Central Station and F.E.A.S.T. shelter fire incident, anyway), and he apologizes for behaving in a way that gave her that impression, but the entire gist of the conversation is just set up so Mary Jane can say, “I’m always the one being saved, I just wanted to do the saving once”. 

And it’s here where you can hear the writer’s voice instead of hearing Mary Jane’s voice.

Ultimate Spider-Man (especially the first volume) did a fairly solid job setting up and illustrating Mary Jane’s frustration with being “damseled”, primarily by having it connected to traumatizing events – like Ultimate Green Goblin tossing her off the Brooklyn Bridge, or being taken hostage by one of the Spider-Man clones, and dosed with experimental chemicals that turned her into a monster.

But, Ultimate Spider-Man also did a good job of either making Peter too caught up in his own dramas to notice her issues, or just being too late to help her and struggling find a medium of empathetic and supportive, which could sometimes teeter into overprotective or insensitive. In both instances, Mary Jane’s anger toward Peter and her circumstance can be justified by things within the narrative.

There’s nothing like that here in Marvel’s Spider-Man. Mary Jane makes several side-eye comments like, “Nah, I’m not gonna call Peter, he’ll just tell me go home and sit at my laptop” at different intervals of her stealth segments, and it’s like, “Um, when did this occur, exactly?”

If she wasn’t already looking things up in the game’s narrative (because a majority of your time with Mary Jane is talking to her on the phone and listening to her talk about what she found doing research), the two of them are not talking at all because she’s not integral to that bit of the game’s narrative. 

I know a lot of this is just an excuse or contrivance for gameplay. Mary Jane has to be thrown into the middle of a situation that anyone with common sense would avoid, so that the player can literally play as her. But, as a result of these gameplay contrivances, you end up with disingenuous drama between Peter and Mary Jane.

(And the one time he actually tells her, “Mary Jane stay back, I don’t want to have to save you too!” she’s oddly noncommittal about how blunt that was, and stays back.)

Insomniac has gone record with their opinion that Mary Jane Watson is not much else than a damsel and that they wanted to change that. But, their opinion seems entirely based on an era comic books she initially appeared in that haven’t been relevant beyond historical reference. 

And for the most part, Mary Jane’s role in the 60s era Spider-Man comics were brief or supporting appearances that established her as the mysterious blind date, or, the party girl everyone wanted to be around. (I’m not 100% sure when the history of her family trauma came into the picture.)

Basically, it seems to me, however much you’ve either read or watched of Spider-Man, no matter how much Mary Jane might’ve evolved as a character across the decades the comic has been running, the only Mary Jane Watson people remember is 60s Mary Jane when a certain image or attitude about women was reinforced. (It’s not dissimilar to people insisting that “Peter Parker must be a teenager” or “Peter Parker must be unmarried” whenever faced with the responsibility of writing adult-era Peter Parker.)

And if it’s not 60s’ Mary Jane, then its Sam Raimi’s Mary Jane, who was accosted and abducted throughout the film series by Green Goblin, Doctor Octopus, and Venom, because she was unfortunate enough to know Peter Parker.

It’s an issue when the biggest impression that your female character leaves is being thrown into a state of “constant” peril with her superhero boyfriend to rescue her (either as a romantic sentiment or just to demonstrate just how superhuman he is). You, as a fan, can pull out examples of the contrary all the live-long-day, but if that is the prevailing impression within pop culture then that speaks to a larger problem with the representation of women in general and how they’re written by men. 

I don’t think it’s going to stop any time soon, especially in such an insular good-ole-boys industry as the comic book business (where it’s asking too much to draw anatomically correct women in costumes that don’t look painted on), but this is not me saying “stop refuting things with facts”.

As a writer, it’s your responsibility to collect evidence to the contrary, use those clarifications in your story – that while they be an exception and not the rule – so you’re not perpetuating what is often only a half-true statement. Research the thing you’re talking about, basically. I mean, yeah, Mary Jane’s been put in the hot seat quite a few times – that’s a fact. But she’s also been in situations – in any iteration of the character you can think of – where she either worked together with Spider-Man, or didn’t even need Spider-Man at all to get out of a situation. 

(I’m also inclined to believe that the number of times she’s appeared and nothing happens to her far outweighs the number of times she been in trouble with the requirement that Spider-Man needed to save her. But, that’s me.)

Like, for the longest time, Spider-Man: The Animated Series was (for me) the biggest example of a damseled Mary Jane as much as it made her capable of getting away from obsessive stalker boyfriends like Hydro Man, and then there’s Ultimate Spider-Man’s tightrope walk of putting her danger and putting her in situations wherein she got out without Peter’s help, or with his help, then addressing that. 

I don’t think the writing for Mary Jane in this video game is necessarily bad, I think they did an otherwise solid job of capturing her character and her voice, but, there is a clear distinction between whom speaking the further the game goes on. Sometimes it’s Mary Jane, as evidence in the earlier parts of the game and later when that whole argument subplot is done and over with.

But, most of the time it’s Insomniac’s writers soap-boxing about an issue that’s not much of an issue when you know how to handle it. In this instance, I don’t think they handled it because they didn’t know to create legitimate conflict between Peter and Mary Jane without going over old ground with nothing particularly new or insightful to say.

There’s showing how determined or dedicated a character is to their job, regardless of the danger, and then there’s creating scenarios where your character ends up looking incredibly unseasonable, and irresponsible. This is the latter.

(Also, if you’re going to reblog this, for-the-love-of-mike, don’t put long ass comic book scans on this post. Thanks. You will also catch the fastest block in the west if you decide be a vitriolic stan.)

And it’s here where you can hear the writer’s voice instead of hearing Mary Jane’s voice.

Ultimate Spider-Man (especially the first volume) did a fairly solid job setting up and illustrating Mary Jane’s frustration with being “damseled”, primarily by having it connected to traumatizing events – like Ultimate Green Goblin tossing her off the Brooklyn Bridge, or being taken hostage by one of the Spider-Man clones, and dosed with experimental chemicals that turned her into a monster.

But, Ultimate Spider-Man also did a good job of either making Peter too caught up in his own dramas to notice her issues, or just being too late to help her and struggling find a medium of empathetic and supportive, which could sometimes teeter into overprotective or insensitive. In both instances, Mary Jane’s anger toward Peter and her circumstance can be justified by things within the narrative.

There’s nothing like that here in Marvel’s Spider-Man. Mary Jane makes several side-eye comments like, “Nah, I’m not gonna call Peter, he’ll just tell me go home and sit at my laptop” at different intervals of her stealth segments, and it’s like, “Um, when did this occur, exactly?”

If she wasn’t already looking things up in the game’s narrative (because a majority of your time with Mary Jane is talking to her on the phone and listening to her talk about what she found doing research), the two of them are not talking at all because she’s not integral to that bit of the game’s narrative. 

I know a lot of this is just an excuse or contrivance for gameplay. Mary Jane has to be thrown into the middle of a situation that anyone with common sense would avoid, so that the player can literally play as her. But, as a result of these gameplay contrivances, you end up with disingenuous drama between Peter and Mary Jane.

(And the one time he actually tells her, “Mary Jane stay back, I don’t want to have to save you too!” she’s oddly noncommittal about how blunt that was, and stays back.)

Insomniac has gone record with their opinion that Mary Jane Watson is not much else than a damsel and that they wanted to change that. But, their opinion seems entirely based on an era comic books she initially appeared in that haven’t been relevant beyond historical reference. 

And for the most part, Mary Jane’s role in the 60s era Spider-Man comics were brief or supporting appearances that established her as the mysterious blind date, or, the party girl everyone wanted to be around. (I’m not 100% sure when the history of her family trauma came into the picture.)

Basically, it seems to me, however much you’ve either read or watched of Spider-Man, no matter how much Mary Jane might’ve evolved as a character across the decades the comic has been running, the only Mary Jane Watson people remember is 60s Mary Jane when a certain image or attitude about women was reinforced. (It’s not dissimilar to people insisting that “Peter Parker must be a teenager” or “Peter Parker must be unmarried” whenever faced with the responsibility of writing adult-era Peter Parker.)

And if it’s not 60s’ Mary Jane, then its Sam Raimi’s Mary Jane, who was accosted and abducted throughout the film series by Green Goblin, Doctor Octopus, and Venom, because she was unfortunate enough to know Peter Parker.

It’s an issue when the biggest impression that your female character leaves is being thrown into a state of “constant” peril with her superhero boyfriend to rescue her (either as a romantic sentiment or just to demonstrate just how superhuman he is). You, as a fan, can pull out examples of the contrary all the live-long-day, but if that is the prevailing impression within pop culture then that speaks to a larger problem with the representation of women in general and how they’re written by men. 

I don’t think it’s going to stop any time soon, especially in such an insular good-ole-boys industry as the comic book business (where it’s asking too much to draw anatomically correct women in costumes that don’t look painted on), but this is not me saying “stop refuting things with facts”.

As a writer, it’s your responsibility to collect evidence to the contrary, use those clarifications in your story – that while they be an exception and not the rule – so you’re not perpetuating what is often only a half-true statement. Research the thing you’re talking about, basically. I mean, yeah, Mary Jane’s been put in the hot seat quite a few times – that’s a fact. But she’s also been in situations – in any iteration of the character you can think of – where she either worked together with Spider-Man, or didn’t even need Spider-Man at all to get out of a situation. 

(I’m also inclined to believe that the number of times she’s appeared and nothing happens to her far outweighs the number of times she been in trouble with the requirement that Spider-Man needed to save her. But, that’s me.)

Like, for the longest time, Spider-Man: The Animated Series was (for me) the biggest example of a damseled Mary Jane as much as it made her capable of getting away from obsessive stalker boyfriends like Hydro Man, and then there’s Ultimate Spider-Man’s tightrope walk of putting her danger and putting her in situations wherein she got out without Peter’s help, or with his help, then addressing that. 

I don’t think the writing for Mary Jane in this video game is necessarily bad, I think they did an otherwise solid job of capturing her character and her voice, but, there is a clear distinction between whom speaking the further the game goes on. Sometimes it’s Mary Jane, as evidence in the earlier parts of the game and later when that whole argument subplot is done and over with.

But, most of the time it’s Insomniac’s writers soap-boxing about an issue that’s not much of an issue when you know how to handle it. In this instance, I don’t think they handled it because they didn’t know to create legitimate conflict between Peter and Mary Jane without going over old ground with nothing particularly new or insightful to say.

There’s showing how determined or dedicated a character is to their job, regardless of the danger, and then there’s creating scenarios where your character ends up looking incredibly unseasonable, and irresponsible. This is the latter.

(Also, if you’re going to reblog this, for-the-love-of-mike, don’t put long ass comic book scans on this post. Thanks. You will also catch the fastest block in the west if you decide be a vitriolic stan.)
trail.content:
I have no real problems with Mary Jane being a reporter instead of a model or actress, especially considering that’s the path she was on (more or less) near the end of the Ultimate Marvel series in Ultimate Comics Spider-Man (IIRC). (I don’t think that was exclusive to the Disney cartoon.)

(If you can deal with her being a mother and a superhero, sometimes both at the same time, you can deal with her not being a model/actress in every iteration there is for her).

It certainly is more convenient for the game’s narrative. (it’s akin to the 2016 Frequency remake making Frank Sullivan a police officer versus a fireman who clumsily detective’ed his way through a serial killer case). I like the switch, especially since Peter (in this iteration of his story) is more scientist than he is reporter. (But, I also like Peter telling Mary Jane the truth in USM, so you know where I stand in general, I guess.) 

Insomniac’s writing for Mary Jane for the most part, is fairly solid, but there are times where it’s pretty… irresponsible (for lack of a better word). That, or just really inconsistent for the sake of “character does things because plot”.  I like reporter Mary Jane, what I’m not crazy about, I guess, is that making her a reporter for the Daily Bugle seems, not at all inspired by other canon material, but a tried and true argument that has become pretty disingenuous over the years.

For the most part, a lot of the writing early on in the game never presents Mary Jane or Peter Parker’s relationship as one where Peter is overprotective or dismissive of her journalistic efforts. Hell, he doesn’t even talk down to her when she decides to jump into situation wherein she could be hurt. He just expresses his worry.

Her introduction, for instance, wherein she is trying to expose Fisk for stealing (?) historical art pieces and selling them off as legit purchases, demonstrates nothing but complete trust between the two characters, especially with regard to what she can and cannot do. Mary Jane can sneak up on a guy and knock him out (when he’s distracted), as long as there aren’t other men around that can kill her the next second.

Mary Jane knows she can’t fight or even handle the Martin Li’s “Demon gang”, so she removes herself from the equation by hiding somewhere, and only ends up in the middle of things when one of Li’s henchmen is smart enough to do a thorough search of the exhibit she’s in. Then Peter has to come and help her out. 

Afterward, a lot of Peter and Mary Jane’s interaction highlights and centralizes her primary skill in this universe: investigation, digging things up, the thing that’s kinda integral to her job at the Daily Bugle. It even demonstrates, for the most part, that her devil-may-care antics come with legal consequences (not that they appear lasting or impactful, but they’re there). And, never once does she complain about having to look things up, either for herself or for Peter – especially when they start working on the same story (the “Demon gang”).

But, following Wilson Fisk’s arrest and the introduction of Martin Li (Mr. Negative) as the antagonist, Mary Jane’s attitude toward Peter becomes questionably antagonistic. A lot of it is an artificial conflict so that Peter and Mary Jane have something to fight about. (It’s not enough that their not together because of issues with him being Spider-Man 80% of the time, as usual.) 

Mary Jane starts taking what are, really, some seriously unnecessary risks to get answers for questions she might’ve uncovered by just talking to the persons in question or nosing into people’s paper trails. Like, instead of stealth segments, maybe we could’ve gotten L.A. Noir type levels with Mary Jane trying to investigate crimes for articles. Hell, that would’ve been a perfect excuse to use Yuri Watanabe more in the narrative outside of phone calls and brief cinematics, but I digress.

Instead, she goes straight into armed gunman territory to speak to one of Osborn’s aide’s (around the same time Peter is), without telling Peter about it. She nearly causes a scene by surprising said aide, and then again when Peter drops in when rescues her from what he assumed was a mercenary working for Silver Sable. She then proceeds to get mad at Peter for admonishing her actions, showing the slightest concern about her decisions, and behaves as though Peter told her to stay out of the situation (when that never occurred).

She even goes as far as to say that the reason they broke up (in this universe) is because he was somehow impeding her career as a journalist, when the reason, as usual, seems to be she just got frustrated with how much time he dedicated to being Spider-Man versus his interpersonal relationships (which is why the narrative has him repeatedly emphasize that his work with Doctor Octopus is the better time sink. He has time for a personal life, at the very least).

But, the narrative never treats her comments as though, out of frustration, she blindly assigned blame of their relationship problems on the wrong issue (in this particular instance). It’s a fact, despite Peter’s protests to otherwise (which I guess are just wrong?).

The narrative paints this image that instead of doing what they were doing in the introduction level, Peter has spent most of her career at the Bugle (and before that), telling her what she can and cannot investigate based on the level of danger, when the most he’s done is say, “Mary Jane this is dangerous. Did you really think this all the way through? Why didn’t tell me about this so I could help you?” 

There’s this insistence from Mary Jane that the two of them are partners or could be partners, but that partnership is based only on when its useful for her, and then when she gets into a situation that actually requires his help, she bristles when he points out she was acting recklessly then proceeds to give him the silent treatment.

And, obviously, the two finally sit down and talk. She apologies for acting the way she does (after the Grand Central Station and F.E.A.S.T. shelter fire incident, anyway), and he apologizes for behaving in a way that gave her that impression, but the entire gist of the conversation is just set up so Mary Jane can say, “I’m always the one being saved, I just wanted to do the saving once”. 

And it’s here where you can hear the writer’s voice instead of hearing Mary Jane’s voice.

Ultimate Spider-Man (especially the first volume) did a fairly solid job setting up and illustrating Mary Jane’s frustration with being “damseled”, primarily by having it connected to traumatizing events – like Ultimate Green Goblin tossing her off the Brooklyn Bridge, or being taken hostage by one of the Spider-Man clones, and dosed with experimental chemicals that turned her into a monster.

But, Ultimate Spider-Man also did a good job of either making Peter too caught up in his own dramas to notice her issues, or just being too late to help her and struggling find a medium of empathetic and supportive, which could sometimes teeter into overprotective or insensitive. In both instances, Mary Jane’s anger toward Peter and her circumstance can be justified by things within the narrative.

There’s nothing like that here in Marvel’s Spider-Man. Mary Jane makes several side-eye comments like, “Nah, I’m not gonna call Peter, he’ll just tell me go home and sit at my laptop” at different intervals of her stealth segments, and it’s like, “Um, when did this occur, exactly?”

If she wasn’t already looking things up in the game’s narrative (because a majority of your time with Mary Jane is talking to her on the phone and listening to her talk about what she found doing research), the two of them are not talking at all because she’s not integral to that bit of the game’s narrative. 

I know a lot of this is just an excuse or contrivance for gameplay. Mary Jane has to be thrown into the middle of a situation that anyone with common sense would avoid, so that the player can literally play as her. But, as a result of these gameplay contrivances, you end up with disingenuous drama between Peter and Mary Jane.

(And the one time he actually tells her, “Mary Jane stay back, I don’t want to have to save you too!” she’s oddly noncommittal about how blunt that was, and stays back.)

Insomniac has gone record with their opinion that Mary Jane Watson is not much else than a damsel and that they wanted to change that. But, their opinion seems entirely based on an era comic books she initially appeared in that haven’t been relevant beyond historical reference. 

And for the most part, Mary Jane’s role in the 60s era Spider-Man comics were brief or supporting appearances that established her as the mysterious blind date, or, the party girl everyone wanted to be around. (I’m not 100% sure when the history of her family trauma came into the picture.)

Basically, it seems to me, however much you’ve either read or watched of Spider-Man, no matter how much Mary Jane might’ve evolved as a character across the decades the comic has been running, the only Mary Jane Watson people remember is 60s Mary Jane when a certain image or attitude about women was reinforced. (It’s not dissimilar to people insisting that “Peter Parker must be a teenager” or “Peter Parker must be unmarried” whenever faced with the responsibility of writing adult-era Peter Parker.)

And if it’s not 60s’ Mary Jane, then its Sam Raimi’s Mary Jane, who was accosted and abducted throughout the film series by Green Goblin, Doctor Octopus, and Venom, because she was unfortunate enough to know Peter Parker.

It’s an issue when the biggest impression that your female character leaves is being thrown into a state of “constant” peril with her superhero boyfriend to rescue her (either as a romantic sentiment or just to demonstrate just how superhuman he is). You, as a fan, can pull out examples of the contrary all the live-long-day, but if that is the prevailing impression within pop culture then that speaks to a larger problem with the representation of women in general and how they’re written by men. 

I don’t think it’s going to stop any time soon, especially in such an insular good-ole-boys industry as the comic book business (where it’s asking too much to draw anatomically correct women in costumes that don’t look painted on), but this is not me saying “stop refuting things with facts”.

As a writer, it’s your responsibility to collect evidence to the contrary, use those clarifications in your story – that while they be an exception and not the rule – so you’re not perpetuating what is often only a half-true statement. Research the thing you’re talking about, basically. I mean, yeah, Mary Jane’s been put in the hot seat quite a few times – that’s a fact. Like, for the longest time, Spider-Man: The Animated Series was (for me) the biggest example of a damseled Mary Jane as much as it made her capable of getting away from obsessive stalker boyfriends like Hydro Man, and then there’s Ultimate Spider-Man’s tightrope walk of putting her danger and putting her in situations wherein she got out without Peter’s help, or with his help, then addressing that.

summary: This is dumb but one of my actual favourite things in Spiderman was the voice acting, especially towards the end of the series...
body: This is dumb but one of my actual favourite things in Spiderman was the voice acting, especially towards the end of the series when things are really heating up- there was so much emotion in Peter’s voice, you could actually feel exactly what he was feeling from the way he delivered his lines, it’s such an underrated skill!

reblog.comment: This is dumb but one of my actual favourite things in Spiderman was the voice acting, especially towards the end of the series when things are really heating up- there was so much emotion in Peter’s voice, you could actually feel exactly what he was feeling from the way he delivered his lines, it’s such an underrated skill!

summary:
Oh. My. God.
That was fucking AWESOME. That was such an incredible, impressive, hilarious but sincere and heartfelt journey. It...
body:
Oh. My. God.

That was fucking AWESOME. That was such an incredible, impressive, hilarious but sincere and heartfelt journey. It was both action packed and honest, with moments of fantastic tension but also very down-to-earth emotional moments. They did an amazing job with it!!

Thank you for yet another incredible journey, Jack, for bringing us all along on the adventure! I loved every single second of it and I’m so excited for whatever’s next 😁💚

summary: Spidey is literally the communities favourite!!
